item.title: Magnetic order and Li diffusion in the $\frac{1}{3}$-filled kagome layers of the antiperovskite lithium-ion battery materials $({\mathrm{Li}}_{2}\mathrm{Fe})\mathrm{SO}$ and $({\mathrm{Li}}_{2}\mathrm{Fe})\mathrm{SeO}$
item.description:
Author(s): F. Seewald, T. Schulze, N. Gräßler, F. L. Carstens, L. Singer, M. A. A. Mohamed, S. Hampel, B. Büchner, R. Klingeler, H.-H. Klauss, and H.-J. Grafe

The lithium-rich antiperovskites (Li2Fe)SeO and (Li2Fe)SO host nonmagnetic lithium and magnetic iron on the same atomic position. These sites form a 3-D network of triangles with geometric frustration in the diluted antiferromagnetic lattice. Here, the authors perform magnetization, Mössbauer, and NMR studies that reveal a long-range antiferromagnetically ordered ground state below T ≈ 50 K and a regime of short-range magnetic correlations up to 100 K. The results are consistent with a random Li-Fe distribtion on the shared lattice position. In addition, Li-hopping is observed above 200 K with an activation energy of Ea = 0.47 eV.


[Phys. Rev. B 112, 094443] Published Mon Sep 22, 2025

item.title: Undulation-induced moiré superlattices with one-dimensional polarization domains and flat bands in two-dimensional bilayer semiconductors
item.description:
Author(s): Xingfu Li, Sunny Gupta, and Boris I. Yakobson

Topographical deformation offers a versatile knob for creating novel electronic phases in two-dimensional materials. Here, the authors demonstrate theoretically that one-dimensional periodic bending of a hexagonal boron nitride bilayer drives gradually varying interlayer shear that causes one-dimensional moiré polarization domains producing one-dimensional electronic flat bands. Such zero Gaussian curvature undulations create slide-type off-plane polarization, also mirrored in double-wall BN nanotubes, and a shear deformation potential that yields one-dimensional quantum-well-like states, together establishing “curvatronics” as a route to exotic phases.


[Phys. Rev. B 112, 115308] Published Fri Sep 19, 2025

item.title: Ultrafast x-ray diffraction of high-pressure phases in dynamically compressed ${\mathrm{TiO}}_{2}$
item.description:
Author(s): I. K. Ocampo, R. F. Smith, D. Kim, V. Prakapenka, S. Speziale, M. Schoelmerich, K. Appel, D. N. Polsin, M. Marshall, S. J. Tracy, F. Miozzi, H. J. Lee, E. Galtier, E. Cunningham, C. McGuire, C. Vennari, A. E. Gleason, and T. S. Duffy

The authors combine here in situ femtosecond x-ray diffraction with laser velocimetry to map high-pressure phase transitions in shock compressed polycrystalline and single-crystal rutile (TiO2). Their results reveal the emergence of a distorted fluorite structure and the ultrafast synthesis of the Fe2P-type phase at pressures well below the equilibrium phase boundary. These transformations occur on nanosecond timescales, highlighting the unique pathways enabled by high-strain-rate loading and offering new insights into metastable phase formation in oxide materials.


[Phys. Rev. B 112, 104103] Published Wed Sep 17, 2025
